snippet: New York City is taking a more aggressive stance against people who have been wounded by police bullets, often moving to have the cases thrown out before trial.
abstract: New York City is taking a more aggressive stance against people who have been wounded by police bullets and then sued, essentially refusing to settle cases and moving to have them thrown out before trial; since 2011, 16 bystanders have been struck by police bullets in city; Law Department spokesman says that police officers' split-second decisions to use deadly force must be protected from second-guessing.
lead_paragraph: New York City is taking a more aggressive stance against people who have been wounded by police bullets, often moving to have the cases thrown out before trial.

headline.main: Bystanders Shot by the Police Face an Uphill Fight to Win Lawsuits
headline.print_headline: Bystanders Shot by the Police Face an Uphill Fight to Win Lawsuits
